class JumpScale.baselib.codetools.RegexTools.RegexTools[source]¶
extractBlocks(text, blockStartPatterns=['.*'], blockStartPatternsNegative=[], blockStopPatterns=[], blockStopPatternsNegative=[], linesIncludePatterns=['.*'], linesExcludePatterns=[], includeMatchingLine=True)[source]¶

look for blocks starting with line which matches one of patterns in blockStartPatterns and not matching one of patterns in blockStartPatternsNegative block will stop when line found which matches one of patterns in blockStopPatterns and not in blockStopPatternsNegative or when next match for start is found in block lines matching linesIncludePatterns will be kept and reverse for linesExcludePatterns example pattern: ‘^class ‘ looks for class at beginning of line with space behind

extractFirstFoundBlock(text, blockStartPatterns, blockStartPatternsNegative=[], blockStopPatterns=[], blockStopPatternsNegative=[], linesIncludePatterns=['.*'], linesExcludePatterns=[], includeMatchingLine=True)[source]¶
findAll(pattern, text, flags=0)[source]¶

Search all matches of pattern in text and returns an array @param pattern: Regex pattern to search for @param text: Text to search in

findHtmlBlock(subject, tofind, path, dieIfNotFound=True)[source]¶

only find 1 block ideal to find e.g. body & header of html doc

findHtmlElement(subject, tofind, path, dieIfNotFound=True)[source]¶
findLine(regex, text)[source]¶

returns line when found @param regex is what we are looking for @param text, we are looking into

findOne(pattern, text, flags=0)[source]¶

Searches for a one match only on pattern inside text, will throw a RuntimeError if more than one match found @param pattern: Regex pattern to search for @param text: Text to search in

getINIAlikeVariableFromText(variableName, text, isArray=False)[source]¶

e.g. in text ‘ test= something testarray = 1,2,4,5 ‘ getINIAlikeVariable(“test”,text) will return ‘something’ @isArray when True and , in result will make array out of getINIAlikeVariable(“testarray”,text,True) will return [1,2,4,5]

getRegexMatch(pattern, text, flags=0)[source]¶

find the first match in the string that matches the pattern. @return RegexMatch object, or None if didn’t match any.

getRegexMatches(pattern, text, flags=0)[source]¶

match all occurences and find start and stop in text return RegexMatches (is array of RegexMatch)

match(pattern, text)[source]¶

search if there is at least 1 match

matchAllText(pattern, text)[source]¶
matchMultiple(patterns, text)[source]¶

see if any patterns matched if patterns=[] then will return False

processLines(text, includes='', excludes='')[source]¶

includes happens first excludes last both are arrays

removeLines(pattern, text)[source]¶

remove lines based on pattern

replace(regexFind, regexFindsubsetToReplace, replaceWith, text)[source]¶

Search for regexFind in text and if found, replace the subset regexFindsubsetToReplace of regexFind with replacewith and returns the new text Example:

replace(“Q-Layer Server”, “Server”, “Computer”, “This is a Q-Layer Server”) will return “This is a Q-Layer Computer”

@param regexFind: String to search for, can be a regular expression @param regexFindsubsetToReplace: The subset within regexFind that you want to replace @param replacewith: The replacement @param text: Text where you want to search and replace

replaceLines(replaceFunction, arg, text, includes='', excludes='')[source]¶

includes happens first (includes of regexes eg @process.* matches full line starting with @process) excludes last both are arrays replace the matched line with line being processed by the functionreplaceFunction(arg,lineWhichMatches) the replace function has 2 params, argument & the matching line

yieldRegexMatches(pattern, text, flags=0)[source]¶

The same as getRegexMatches but instead of returning a list that contains all matches it uses yield to return a generator object witch would improve the performance of the search function.

block will be inserted at linenr, means line with linenr will be moved backwards

matchBlocksDelimiter(startpattern, blockname, delimiteropen='{', delimiterclose='}')[source]¶

will look for startpattern, then scan for delimeropen and then start counting, block will stop when asmany closes are found as open delimiters ideal find e.g. a code block which is not line based will only work on text which is not part of known blocks yet @startpattern example to find ‘{listen,’ startpattern=”^[ ]*{[ ]*listen[ ]*,” #note the way how we allow tabs,newlines and spaces

matchBlocksPattern(startpattern, stoppattern, blockname)[source]¶
will look for startpattern, then scan for stoppattern will only work on text which is not part of known blocks yet example to find comments which are full line based startpattern=’^[ ]*%%’ stoppattern=”

“

Allow manipulate of a text file ideal to manipulate e.g. config files BE CAREFULL, CHANGES ON textfileeditor and chareditor can overwrite each other

addItemToFoundLineOnlyOnce(tofind, add, ignoreRegex=None, reset=False)[source]¶

look for tofind and only one add $add to it, will not do this on lines matching the regexes @param reset if True, will remove the regex first, means will always be added

getTextLineEditor()[source]¶
removeSection(sectionName)[source]¶

look for section starting with ### $sectionName end of section starts with ###END $sectionName delete that part

replace(regexFind, regexFindsubsetToReplace, replaceWith)[source]¶

Search for regexFind in text and if found, replace the subset regexFindsubsetToReplace of regexFind with replacewith and returns the new text Example:

replace(“Q-Layer Server”, “Server”, “Computer”, “This is a Q-Layer Server”) will return “This is a Q-Layer Computer”

@param regexFind: String to search for, can be a regular expression @param regexFindsubsetToReplace: The subset within regexFind that you want to replace @param replacewith: The replacement

replace1Line(newcontent, includes='', excludes='')[source]¶

includes happens first excludes last both are arrays replace matching lines with new content

replace1LineFromFunction(replaceFunction, argument, includes='', excludes='')[source]¶

same as with replaceLinesFromFunction, but only 1 line will be matched

replaceLines(newcontent, includes='', excludes='')[source]¶

includes happens first (is regex!!!!) excludes last both are arrays replace matching lines with new content

replaceLinesFromFunction(replaceFunction, argument, includes='', excludes='')[source]¶

includes happens first excludes last both are arrays @param argument which is going to be give to replacefunction @replaceFunction is the replace function has 2 params, argument & the matching line, returns the processed line replace the matched line with line being processed by the functionreplaceFunction(argument,lineWhichMatches)

replaceNonRegex(tofind, replaceWith)[source]¶
save(filepath=None)[source]¶

write the manipulated file to a new path or to the original

setSection(sectionName, content)[source]¶

look for section starting with ### $sectionName end of section starts with ###END $sectionName whatever inbetween will be replaced by content

if section does not exist yet then it will be added at end of file

matchBlocks(blockname, blockStartPatterns=['.*'], blockStartPatternsNegative=[], blockStopPatterns=[], blockStopPatternsNegative=[], blockfilter='')[source]¶

walk over blocks which are marked as matched and split blocks in more blocks depending criteria can be usefull to do this multiple times (sort of iterative) e.g. find class and then in class remove comments @param blockfilter will always match beginning of blockname e.g. can use userauth.sites then change userauth.sites will match all sites look for blocks starting with line which matches one of patterns in blockStartPatterns and not matching one of patterns in blockStartPatternsNegative block will stop when line found which matches one of patterns in blockStopPatterns and not in blockStopPatternsNegative or when next match for start is found example pattern: ‘^class ‘ looks for class at beginning of line with space behind

replaceBlock(blockname, text, blocknr=1)[source]¶

set block based on startline with new content

JumpScale.baselib.codetools.WordReplacer module¶

reset()[source]¶
synonymAdd(name='', simpleSearch='', regexFind='', regexFindForReplace='', replaceWith='', replaceExclude='', addConfluenceLinkTags=False)[source]¶

Adds a new synonym to this replacer @param name: Synonym name @param simpleSearch: Search text for sysnonym, if you supply this, then the synonym will automatically generate a matching regex pattern that’ll be used to search for this string, if you want to specificy the regex explicitly then use regexFind instead. @param regexFind: Provide this regex only if you didn’t provide simpleSearch, it represents the regex that’ll be used in search for this synonym . It overrides the default synonym search pattern @param regexFindForReplace: The subset within regexFind that’ll be replaced for this synonym

synonymsAddFromFile(path, addConfluenceLinkTags=False)[source]¶

load synonym satements from a file in the following format [searchStatement]:[replaceto] or ‘[regexFind]’:’[regexReplace]’:replaceto note: delimiter is : note: ‘’ around regex statements e.g. ** master?daemon:ApplicationServer application?server:ApplicationServer ‘application[ -_]+server’:’application[ -_]+server’:ApplicationServer ‘[application[ -_]+server]’:’application[ -_]+server’:ApplicationServer ** @param addConfluenceLinkTags id True then replaced items will be surrounded by [] (Boolean)

synonymsPrint()[source]¶
